__data__.text: Picardo was born in Cádiz, Spain, in 1919 to parents Alvaro Picardo de Celis and a mother from the Castellón family.

Picardo, born in Spain in 1919, was raised with four brothers, one of whom passed away in infancy. After his father's death in 1929, he relocated with his remaining family to Madrid, where he started his high school studies at the Instituto de Bachillerato Cervantes.

After finishing high school at the Instituto de Bachillerato Cervantes in Madrid, Picardo had aspirations to enter the navy; however, his plans were hindered by the closure of military academies in Madrid under the Second Spanish Republic.

Following his dream to join the navy being obstructed by the closing of military schools in Madrid under the Second Spanish Republic, Picardo decided to pursue law studies, only to encounter another setback when the Spanish Civil War began in July 1936, interrupting his course while he was 17 years old. Instead, he pivoted to studying architecture.

Determined to continue his education despite the Spanish Civil War, Picardo started studying architecture under the guidance of Luis Moya Blanco, an architect and professor 15 years older, to prevent being evacuated from Madrid. This shift in focus allowed him to remain in the city and continue his education at the Higher Technical School of Architecture of Madrid.

Picardo's aptitude in architecture led Moya Blanco to suggest he switch from law to architecture. Due to the Spanish Civil War and the subsequent dictatorship, many architects were lost, leading to a shortage in the field, with some former successful architects not surviving the war. This context led Moya Blanco to encourage Picardo's pursuit of architecture.

The Spanish Civil War and Franco's dictatorship caused many architects to flee or be banned from the profession, resulting in a shortage. In response, the Dirección General de Aquitectura was established by Franco's regime to oversee architecture and support national reconstruction. Some architects were unable to continue their careers due to exile or disqualification.

In the aftermath of the Spanish Civil War and Franco's dictatorship, Picardo began his professional career as a mural painter at the age of 20, with his first commission taking place in 1939 at the Cine Fígaro (Figaro Cinema) in Madrid, completed for his architect mentor, Luis Moya Blanco, due to his exceptional artistic talents and perspective skills.

After starting his career at 20, Picardo mainly supported himself through mural painting in his youth and early professional years, with his talent and perspective skills earning him his first commission at the Cine Fígaro from his architect mentor, Luis Moya Blanco.

In his student days, Picardo started doing illustrations for numerous articles and eventually the covers of the Spanish architectural publications, Revista Nacional de Arquitectura and Boletín de la Dirección General de Arquitectura, showcasing his artistic skills beyond mural painting.

After Picardo's student years, he gained recognition for his detailed illustrations of Madrid in the 1950s and 1960s, the Spanish protectorate in Morocco, and a series of sketches depicting the Canary Islands, which he completed in 1953. Post-studenthood, Picardo gained acclaim for his intricate illustrations of various locations, including Madrid, the Spanish protectorate in Morocco, and the Canary Islands. Additionally, he developed a keen interest in preserving and restoring historic architecture, which led him to travel extensively throughout Spain and abroad to study buildings.
